subject: Economics
title: Public Goods: The Free-Rider Problem
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: Public Goods: The Free-Rider Problem.

hook.text: A lighthouse helps every ship that passes.

buildup.text: Public goods are non-excludable (can't stop free-riders) and non-rivalrous (one person's use doesn't reduce another's).

discovery.text: Free-riding: everyone benefits from the public good, but nobody wants to pay.

twist.text: This is why governments exist in economics.

climax.text: The free-rider problem explains why markets alone can't provide everything society needs.

punchline.text: Markets are brilliant at most things. Public goods are their kryptonite.

quiz.question: Why can't markets efficiently provide public goods?
options: Non-excludability means people can enjoy the benefit without paying, so nobody voluntarily pays enough to fund it
